Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Applying New Tools to the Discovery and Measurement of the New Standard Model
Award.AbstractNarration:
Experimental studies of proton collisions at the LHC are likely to reveal the answers to some of the most fundamental questions in physics. Already, experiments like Fermi GST and PAMELA are producing very exciting - though puzzling - results that may be major hints to an unexpectedly rich dark matter sector. There are many possibilities for dramatic discoveries, which will usher in a new era for dark matter and fundamental particle physics. How one combines the complementary information from these disparate measurements into a cohesive picture is not readily apparent. Initially, it is unlikely that an obvious picture will emerge that is more compelling than conventional explanations, such as poorly understood modeling or experimental systematics. Thus, one must be prepared to pose serious questions about the data, the theoretical interpretation, the experimental systematics, and additional modeling assumptions that are not limited by avoidable technical limitations. This award supports a program of physics research built around a unifying approach to large-scale scientific data analysis, initially dealing with data from LHC experiments, in a way that is scalable with respect to complexity of data, experimental apparatuses, and theoretical models. The approach could have profound impact on early standard model physics measurements and the extension to Higgs physics and beyond as well as facilitate communication and cooperation between ATLAS and CMS, between theorists and experimentalists, and among researchers from different disciplines.
In terms of broader impact the key development in this award that enables the scalable approach to large-scale data analysis is applicable beyond the field of particle physics. Experiments as diverse as Fermi GST, HESS, and the IceCube neutrino telescope are already exploring the use of this technology, which is a concrete indication of the broader impacts of the proposed research. Additional impacts follow from a well-integrated educational and outreach component. A portable and professionally-designed exhibit will be constructed for use at the popular New York City World Science Festival street fair, area science fairs, career fairs, and the like. The booth will utilize existing material from the ATLAS outreach group. Additionally, the exhibit will be the basis for a project integrated into a teaching methods course in the Department of Teaching and Learning at NYU. The project will be to design activities for the exhibit itself and to develop and assess physics teaching methods. Thus, the exhibit, the activities, and the assessment of the exhibit will be the culmination of a semester-long project, and those teachers can bring the developed activities to their own schools. Finally, the PI will mentor high-school students from the Harlem Children's Society so that they can understand and operate the demonstrations, thus serving as peer-group liaisons, and role models for under-represented groups in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US and countries around the world came together to build the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) -- the largest machine ever built -- to explore the world at its most fundamental level. After decades of engineering work the collider turned on and began producing the largest dataset in the history of science. New tools and techniques were necessary to analyze and extract precious information from this huge amount of data. The goal of this CAREER award from the National Science Foundation was to develop and apply the tools necessary to arrive at a more complete understanding of the Universe.

One of the most clear targets for the LHC was the long-sought Higgs boson -- a particle predicted to exist as a consequence of a mechanism that would explain why fundamental particles have mass. The search for this particle required bringing together several pieces of evidence in a comprehensive and consistent statistical framework. Cranmer was one of the main architects of the statistical formalism and software tools that were used to do this. The Higgs particle was discovered in July 2012, attracting world wide attention and leading to the 2013 Nobel Prize in Physics.

Those same tools have been used now to make precise measurements of the Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS experiments to stringently test the so-called Standard Model of particle physics. Thus far the data are consistent with the predictions of the Standard Model, but any significant deviation would be the sign of some new phenomena that would be attributed to new particles or forces. These studies will continue for years as the LHC collects more data and becomes sensitive to more of the Higgs properties.

While the Standard Model is elegant, it is incomplete. Several theories Beyond the Standard Model address its shortcomings, and predict new particles and forces. Thus, we have searched directly for evidence of new particles and interactions, though thus far we have found no significant evidence for them. There are many such theories and as physicist's creativity uncovers more exotic possibilities it has become increasingly important that we develop powerful tools to reinterpret the searches that we have performed. This award has supported the development of strategies that allow us to preserve analyses so that they can be reproduced and reinterpreted in the context of new theories. This is a major contribution to the long-term legacy of this historic investment in science.

The statistical tools and techniques developed as part of this work can be applied beyond the field of particle physics. Large collaborations, complex sensor environments, detailed simulations, and large volumes of data were the challenges that drove innovation for techniques. The essence of these challenges can be found in many other fields. Similarly, the move towards reproducibility, reusability, and reinterpretability of scientific data analysis has become almost universally appreciated. The technical and collaborative challenges of the LHC data analysis environment have driven innovation of new techniques for analysis preservation. We are already finding that these techniques are generic and can power a new generation of scientific services built around valuable data resources. 

Finally, all of these exciting scientific outcomes have come together with a vigourous education and outreach efforts. Graduate students and post docs trained through this grant have continued on in academic and industrial careers. The skills that they developed in the context of this research are enriching our workforce. Our ATLAS exhibit, designed to teach the general public about this work and contributed to by local science teachers, has been displayed at several large science festivals, with estimates of about 10,000 visitors to the exhibit at each of the two USA Science and Engineering Festivals to which it was brought. Moreover, we have taken part in numerous public lectures, print, radio, and television interviews, and short-form videos published on the web that communicate the excitement of basic research to hundreds of thousands of people.
